subject: RE: [junit] Stack overflow crashes GUI test runners
msgSnippet: StackOverFlowError is a subclass of VirtualMachineError like OutOfMemoryError.  VMErrors aren t expected to be caught, though you always can if you really want
messageBody:
StackOverFlowError is a subclass of VirtualMachineError like OutOfMemoryError. VMErrors aren't expected to be caught, though you always can if you really want to. The irony being that if you catch a VirtualMachineError, there's a good chance you won't be able to do anything to recover from it. That is, if you're out of memory and you catch that error, an attempt to clean up, log a message or whatever will likely require memory, which you don't have, so you'll just get another error.

The JVM should never crash though, in the sense of a core dump. If it does, it's likely a JVM bug.

Scott Stirling
JRun QA
Macromedia

Subject: [junit] Stack overflow crashes GUI test runners

Why is it that if two tests overflow the stack, the
AWT and Swing test runners crash? Surely this is
a bug. Here is an example that causes a crash:

import junit.framework.*;

public class IsItABug2 extends TestCase {

public static Test suite() {
TestSuite suite= new TestSuite("Is it a bug 2?");
suite.addTestSuite(IsItABug2.class);
suite.addTestSuite(IsItABug2.class);
return suite ; }

public IsItABug2( String name ) { super(name) ; }

public void testInfRecursion() { infiniteRecursion() ; }

private void infiniteRecursion() { infiniteRecursion() ; }
}

I'm using JDK 1.3.1 and JUnit 3.7.

Cheers,
Theodore Norvell
